intro: Baissea ogowensis, commonly known as the Ogowé mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to the rainforests of Central Africa. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and typically grows on the branches of host trees such as ficus and mahogany. The plant has small, leathery leaves and produces white or yellowish flowers, followed by small, fleshy fruits. It plays a role in the ecosystem by providing food for various birds and insects, while also drawing nutrients from its host. Due to habitat loss, it is considered vulnerable and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
